user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ahc_echo:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
ahc_echo (void *cls, struct MHD_Connection *con, const char *url, const
          char *method, const char *version,
          const char *upload_data, size_t *upload_size, void **req_cls)
{
  struct Holder *holder;
  struct MHD_Response *res;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;
  (void) url;
  (void) method;
  (void) version;
  (void) upload_data;
  (void) upload_size;
  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    *req_cls = (void *) 1;
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  *req_cls = NULL;
  holder = calloc (1, sizeof (struct Holder));
  if (! holder)
    return MHD_NO;
  holder->file = fopen (__FILE__, "rb");
  if (NULL == holder->file)
    goto file_error;
  if (Z_OK != deflateInit (&holder->stream, Z_BEST_COMPRESSION))
    goto stream_error;
  holder->buf = malloc (CHUNK);
  if (NULL == holder->buf)
    goto buf_error;
  res = MHD_create_response_from_callback (MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN, 1024, &read_cb,
                                           holder, &free_cb);
  if (NULL == res)
    goto error;
  ret = MHD_add_response_header (res, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                                 "deflate");
  if (MHD_YES != ret)
    goto res_error;
  ret = MHD_add_response_header (res, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE, "text/x-c");
  if (MHD_YES != ret)
    goto res_error;
  ret = MHD_queue_response (con, MHD_HTTP_OK, res);
res_error:
  MHD_destroy_response (res);
  return ret;
error:
  free (holder->buf);
buf_error:
  deflateEnd (&holder->stream);
stream_error:
  fclose (holder->file);
file_error:
  free (holder);
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The provided code fragment contains no direct calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). Therefore there are no explicit uses in this snippet that immediately violate the rule. The items reported above are locations that should be investigated further because they pass buffers or strings to other modules or allocate buffers that may later be used by callbacks (e.g. read_cb/free_cb) or library routines which are not shown here; those external routines might call string.h functions and could lead to out-of-bounds accesses. Other lines in the function (error handling, deflateInit/deflateEnd, fclose, free, MHD_queue_response, and simple pointer assignments) do not themselves use <string.h> functions nor expose buffer/length relationships that would suggest a potential Rule 21.17 violation within this fragment, so they do not need investigation for this specific rule based on the code shown.
